fact: Great white sharks can detect a single drop of blood in 25 gallons of water.
Tiger sharks are nicknamed 'garbage cans of the sea' because they eat almost anything, including license plates and tires.
Hammerhead sharks have 360-degree vision thanks to their wide-set eyes.
Nurse sharks can create a strong suction to suck prey out of crevices.
Thresher sharks use their long tails like whips to stun schools of fish.
Greenland sharks can live over 400 years, making them the longest-lived vertebrates.
Goblin sharks have extendable jaws that shoot forward to grab prey.
Whale sharks are the largest fish in the world, growing over 40 feet long.
Lemon sharks can return to their birthplace to give birth, a behavior known as natal philopatry.
Bull sharks can survive in both saltwater and freshwater, even swimming far up rivers.
Basking sharks filter up to 2,000 tons of water per hour while feeding on plankton.
Cookiecutter sharks bite circular plugs out of much larger animals, including whales and submarines.
Juvenile zebra sharks have stripes, but as they mature, their stripes turn into spots.
Blacktip sharks often leap out of the water and spin while feeding on schools of fish.
Sand tiger shark embryos eat their siblings inside the womb, a behavior called intrauterine cannibalism.
Megamouth sharks are so rare that fewer than 300 confirmed sightings have ever been recorded.
Porbeagle sharks are one of the few shark species known to play, chasing objects in the water.
Shortfin mako sharks are the fastest sharks, capable of swimming up to 45 mph.
Wobbegong sharks use camouflage to lie in wait and ambush unsuspecting prey.
Frilled sharks are often called 'living fossils' because they have remained unchanged for millions of years.
Swell sharks can gulp water or air to puff up their bodies when threatened.
Blue sharks migrate thousands of miles across oceans each year.
Carpet sharks are known for their ornate patterns that resemble carpets or mosaics.
Horn sharks use their strong jaws to crush hard-shelled prey like sea urchins and crabs.
Sawsharks use their long saw-like snouts lined with teeth to slash through schools of fish.
Angel sharks bury themselves in sand with only their eyes exposed, ambushing prey from below.
Silky sharks get their name from their smooth skin texture.
White tip reef sharks are one of the only sharks that can rest motionless on the ocean floor.
Dusky sharks take up to 20 years to mature, one of the longest times for any shark.
Dogfish sharks were once used as sandpaper because of their rough skin.
Brown catsharks are small, deep-sea sharks often less than 2 feet long.
Epaulette sharks can walk across land using their fins to move between tide pools.
Gulper sharks have huge livers that make up to 20% of their body weight.
Sandbar sharks have the tallest dorsal fin relative to body size of any shark.
Brown-banded bamboo sharks are often kept in aquariums because of their small size and calm nature.
Night sharks are rarely seen because they live in deep waters and only rise to feed at night.
Spiny dogfish were the most abundant shark species for centuries and were heavily fished.
Blacknose sharks get their name from the dark blotch on the tip of their snout.
Sharpnose sharks are named for their long, pointed snouts.
Finetooth sharks travel in large schools, sometimes numbering in the hundreds.
Galapagos sharks are highly territorial and often circle divers curiously.
Graceful sharks look very similar to blacktip sharks but lack the distinct fin markings.
Ganges sharks are critically endangered and live only in India’s Ganges River.
Sharpnose sevengill sharks have seven gill slits instead of the usual five.
Bluntnose sixgill sharks can grow longer than great whites but live in deep waters.
Bigeye threshers have huge eyes adapted to hunting in deep, dark waters.
Oceanic whitetip sharks were once considered the most abundant large animal on Earth.
False catsharks are unusual deep-sea sharks that can swallow large prey whole.
Brown smoothhounds are harmless sharks that feed mostly on crustaceans.
Starspotted smoothhounds are named for the star-like spots on their bodies.
Milk sharks are small coastal sharks named after their pale coloration.
Pajama sharks are covered in dark vertical stripes that resemble striped pajamas.
Slender bamboo sharks are nocturnal and hide in coral crevices during the day.
Dumb gulper sharks are critically endangered due to overfishing for their liver oil.
Longfin mako sharks are rare relatives of the shortfin mako with larger pectoral fins.
Daggernose sharks have long, flattened snouts and are critically endangered.
Graceful catsharks are small, bottom-dwelling sharks that live in the Indian Ocean.
Clouded catsharks are patterned with blotches that help them blend with rocky seafloors.
Ornate wobbegongs are beautifully patterned sharks that blend perfectly into coral reefs.
Barbeled houndsharks have whisker-like barbels near their mouths to help detect prey.
Crested bullhead sharks lay spiral-shaped egg cases that wedge into rocky crevices.
Port Jackson sharks have unique harness-like markings across their bodies.
Spotted wobbegongs have skin flaps around their mouths that resemble seaweed.
Blind sharks are not actually blind; they just close their eyes when taken out of the water.
Flapper skates are rays, close relatives of sharks, and were once called 'skate sharks.'
Roughskin dogfish were a major source of vitamin A during World War II.
Speartooth sharks are among the rarest sharks, living only in a few tropical rivers.
Ornate angel sharks are critically endangered due to bottom trawling.
Tasselled wobbegongs have fringes around their heads that look like coral.
White ghost catsharks are deep-sea sharks discovered only recently.
Small-spotted catsharks are common in European waters and are often called 'dogfish.'
Narrow sawfish are actually rays but are often mistaken for sawsharks.
Pygmy sharks are among the smallest sharks, reaching only about 10 inches long.
Lanternsharks glow in the dark thanks to light-producing organs called photophores.
Longnose spurdogs have venomous spines in front of their dorsal fins.
Velvet belly lanternsharks use bioluminescence to hide from predators below.
Greeneye spurdogs have striking green eyes adapted to deep-sea living.
Smalleye hammerhead sharks are bright yellow on their undersides.
Scalloped hammerheads form massive schools, sometimes with hundreds of individuals.
Great hammerheads are the largest hammerhead species, reaching up to 20 feet.
Smooth hammerheads lack the indentation on the front of the head seen in other hammerheads.
Whitecheek sharks are small sharks found in shallow coastal waters.
Pacific sleeper sharks are slow-moving giants that may live for centuries.
Longnose dogfish live at depths of up to 5,000 feet.
Brown shysharks curl into a ring and cover their eyes with their tails when threatened.
Striped catsharks have bold stripes running the length of their bodies.
Lacepede’s catsharks are named after French naturalist Bernard Germain de Lacépède.
Broadnose sevengill sharks are powerful predators that can hunt seals.
Greeneye dogfish glow bright green when illuminated by light.
Longfin lanternsharks glow to attract mates in the deep sea.
Dwarf lanternsharks are the smallest known shark, only 6 inches long.
Velvet catsharks are rarely seen and live in deep waters.
False catsharks have a flabby body and are sometimes called sofa sharks.
Arabian carpetsharks are nocturnal hunters that hide in reefs during the day.
Broadgill catsharks have wide gill openings compared to other catsharks.
Filetail catsharks have rough, file-like skin texture.
Collared carpetsharks are named for the dark collar-like band around their neck.
Indonesian angel sharks are critically endangered and extremely rare.
African angel sharks are flattened bottom-dwellers that ambush prey.
Japanese sawsharks use barbels on their snouts to detect buried prey.
Western wobbegongs can change color slightly to match their surroundings.
Ornate angel sharks are highly camouflaged and rest on sandy seabeds.
Crooked catsharks are named for their oddly curved backs.
Yellowspotted catsharks have bright spots that help them blend with corals.
Broadfin sharks are rarely seen and live in the deep sea.
Brown catsharks are masters of camouflage, blending into muddy seafloors.
Reticulated swellsharks can inflate their bodies to deter predators.
Northern river sharks live in both rivers and coastal waters in northern Australia.
Speckled catsharks have irregular dark markings across their pale bodies.
Brown lanternsharks use bioluminescence to stay camouflaged from predators below.
Broadnose catsharks are bottom-dwellers found off the coasts of South America.
African catsharks are found only off southern Africa and are rarely studied.
Indonesian bamboo sharks are egg-layers, with spiral egg cases nicknamed 'mermaid’s purses.'
Arabian smoothhounds are harmless sharks that feed mainly on shrimp and small crabs.
Brown guitar sharks have body shapes halfway between rays and true sharks.
Whitefin swellsharks glow under UV light due to biofluorescence.
Sunda bamboo sharks are small and live in shallow coral reefs in Southeast Asia.
Spotted dogfish are small and have a pattern of tiny spots along their backs.
Ornate catsharks have bold patterns that make them popular in public aquariums.
Indonesian houndsharks are critically endangered due to overfishing.
Slender weasel sharks are long and thin, perfectly adapted for fast swimming.
Barbeled catsharks have sensitive feelers around their mouths for detecting prey.
Hasselt’s bamboo sharks are nocturnal, hiding in reef crevices by day.
Broadfin sawtail sharks use serrated snouts to slash prey in schools of fish.
Collared catsharks have a distinctive dark collar mark around the head.
Ornate dogfish are deepwater sharks with striking body patterns.
Indonesian angel sharks are critically endangered due to trawling.
Pyjama sharks live off South Africa and are named for their striped 'pajama' look.
Longsnout dogfish live in the deep sea and are rarely observed alive.
Blackmouth catsharks are small, deepwater sharks with distinctive black mouths.
White ghost catsharks are pale deep-sea sharks first described in the 2010s.
Broadnose dogfish can live at depths greater than 1,000 meters.
Brown shysharks curl into a donut shape when threatened, hiding their eyes with their tails.
Japanese sawtail catsharks are deepwater sharks found off East Asia.
Longfin smoothhounds are migratory sharks that feed mainly on crabs.
Grey bamboo sharks are small, docile reef sharks often kept in aquariums.
Spotted bamboo sharks are beautifully marked with dark blotches.
Brown catsharks are benthic hunters that eat small crustaceans and fish.
Ornate angel sharks are highly camouflaged, blending into sandy seabeds.
Longnose houndsharks have elongated snouts and live along continental shelves.
Philippine catsharks are rarely studied and known only from deep waters around the Philippines.
Hasselt’s catsharks lay spiral-shaped egg cases called mermaid’s purses.
Ornate swellsharks puff up their bodies to avoid being eaten.
Javanese catsharks are small deepwater species found around Java, Indonesia.
Blotched catsharks are patterned with large dark patches.
Dark shysharks curl into rings when threatened, similar to their brown cousins.
Pale spotted catsharks have lighter patterns that help them blend into sandy habitats.
Gulf catsharks are found in the Gulf of Mexico at depths over 600 feet.
Orange-spotted catsharks are named for their bright orange spots.
Western spotted catsharks are found in Australian waters.
African spotted catsharks are bottom-dwelling species from the Indian Ocean.
Atlantic angel sharks were once common but are now endangered from trawling.
Mediterranean angel sharks are critically endangered due to habitat loss.
African angel sharks camouflage perfectly in sandy coastal waters.
Philippines angel sharks are one of the rarest and least studied angel shark species.
Japanese angel sharks are ambush predators that bury themselves in sand to surprise prey.
California angel sharks lie motionless on the seafloor until fish swim close.
Australian angel sharks are critically endangered and live off southern Australia.
Argentine angel sharks are deepwater bottom-dwellers in South American waters.
Burmese bamboo sharks are small reef dwellers with distinct banding.
Broadgill catsharks get their name from their wide gill openings.
Spined pygmy sharks glow in the dark and are among the smallest shark species.
Dwarf lanternsharks hold the record as the smallest known shark, only 8 inches long.
Velvet belly lanternsharks glow on their undersides to hide their silhouette from predators.
Green lanternsharks are deep-sea sharks with glowing organs along their bellies.
Blackbelly lanternsharks live in the Atlantic at depths of 1,500–2,000 feet.
Caribbean lanternsharks are little-studied species from the deep western Atlantic.
Southern lanternsharks are widely distributed in the southern hemisphere.
Brown lanternsharks are found in the Indo-Pacific deep sea and can glow faintly.
Smallfin gulper sharks are critically endangered deep-sea species targeted for oil in their livers.
Leafscale gulper sharks are named for the shape of their scales, resembling tiny leaves.
Broadnose gulper sharks live at depths of up to 1,200 meters.
Blacktail reef sharks are small reef-dwelling species common in the Indo-Pacific.
Tawny nurse sharks are docile bottom-dwellers that suck up prey with powerful mouths.
Ganges river sharks are critically endangered and live only in India’s Ganges River system.
New Guinea river sharks live in both freshwater rivers and coastal seas of Papua New Guinea.
Pigeye sharks closely resemble bull sharks but have larger eyes.
Bali catsharks are beautifully patterned species found around Bali, Indonesia.
Japanese sawsharks have long, saw-like snouts with sharp teeth to slash prey.
African sawsharks live along the southern African coast and use their snouts to detect prey in sand.
Common sawsharks give live birth, unlike many fish with saw-like snouts.
Shortspine spurdogs are deepwater sharks that hunt squid and fish.
Longnose spurdogs have extended snouts and live at depths of up to 1,500 meters.
Roughskin spurdogs have sandpaper-like skin due to their dense dermal denticles.
Greeneye spurdogs have glowing green eyes when viewed under light.
Little gulper sharks are small deep-sea species with large oil-filled livers.
Western gulper sharks live off western Australia and are rarely seen.
Indonesian gulper sharks are overfished for liver oil and are endangered.
Southern dogfish are small bottom-dwelling sharks from Australian waters.
Whitecheek sharks are harmless small sharks found in Indo-Pacific coastal waters.
Spot-tail sharks get their name from the distinct dark spot on their tail fins.
Grey sharpnose sharks are common in Southeast Asia and are small coastal species.
Milk sharks are named for the white color of their meat when cooked.
Graceful sharks are slender species found in the Indian Ocean.
Sliteye sharks have narrow eyes adapted for deep-water living.
Bignose sharks get their name from their large, rounded snouts.
Whitefin sharks are poorly studied species from deep Indo-Pacific waters.
Crocodile sharks are small but powerful predators that live in deep tropical oceans.
Broadfin sharks are rare deepwater sharks with large pectoral fins.
False catsharks have wide, flat heads and are found in very deep waters.
Rough longnose dogfish live in the deep Pacific Ocean and have elongated snouts.
Black dogfish are common deepwater sharks often caught as bycatch.
Harrison’s dogfish are critically endangered sharks off Australia’s east coast.
Greenland sleeper sharks can live for over 400 years, making them the longest-lived vertebrates.
Pacific sleeper sharks are huge deep-sea predators that grow over 20 feet long.
Atlantic sleeper sharks are sluggish deepwater species closely related to Greenland sharks.
Southern sleeper sharks live in cold waters of the Southern Hemisphere.
Northern sawtail catsharks are rarely seen deepwater sharks with distinctive fin shapes.
Spotted gulper sharks have patterns of light spots across their bodies.
Dusky smoothhounds are small bottom-feeding sharks common along the U.S. east coast.
Florida smoothhounds are endemic to the Gulf of Mexico and Florida waters.
Also called gummy sharks, these are commercially fished in Australia for food.
African smoothhounds are found along southern Africa and feed mainly on crustaceans.
White-spotted smoothhounds are named for the bright specks scattered across their bodies.
Narrowfin smoothhounds have thin pectoral fins adapted for maneuvering near the seafloor.
Starry smoothhounds are covered in tiny white star-like spots.
Brown smoothhounds are small coastal sharks often found in bays.
Yellowspotted catsharks are deepwater species with bright yellow markings.
Japanese topesharks are coastal predators found off Japan and Korea.
Hooktooth sharks are rare deepwater species with long, hooked teeth.
Sharpfin houndsharks have sharply pointed fins and are found in South America.
Mexican hornsharks are small bottom dwellers related to the California hornshark.
Ornate wobbegongs have intricate skin patterns that blend perfectly with reefs.
Northern wobbegongs are ambush predators that rest motionless on seafloors.
Spotted wobbegongs are covered in distinctive leopard-like blotches.
Tasseled wobbegongs have elaborate frilly skin flaps around their mouths.
Gulf wobbegongs are found in northern Australia and are well camouflaged.
Network wobbegongs have interconnected markings that look like a net.
Indonesian wobbegongs are newly described species from Indonesian waters.
Giant wobbegongs can grow up to 10 feet long, the largest of their kind.
Speckled carpet sharks have irregular markings that make them look like reef patterns.
Zebra bullhead sharks have striped juvenile patterns that fade as they age.
Portuguese dogfish are deepwater sharks targeted for liver oil.
Knifetooth dogfish are named for their razor-sharp, knife-like teeth.
Roughskin dogfish have rough, sandpaper-like skin from thick dermal denticles.
Smooth lanternsharks lack the heavy denticles found in other lanternsharks.
Black lanternsharks are deepwater bioluminescent sharks found in the Pacific.
Brown lanternsharks glow faintly to hide from predators in the deep sea.
Frilled sharks are living fossils with eel-like bodies and six pairs of gills.
Southern frilled sharks were described as a separate species in 2009.
Striped catsharks have bold vertical stripes running down their bodies.
Humpback catsharks have arched backs and live in deep waters.
Tiger catsharks are patterned with vertical bars, much like tiger sharks.
Pajama catsharks are endemic to South Africa and have striped bodies.
Leopard catsharks are covered in leopard-like spots and blotches.
Narrowtail catsharks have slim tails compared to other catsharks.
White saddled catsharks have distinctive pale saddle-like markings.
Rusty catsharks are named for their reddish-brown coloration.
Izak catsharks are one of the most abundant catsharks in South African waters.
Blackspotted catsharks are patterned with small black dots.
Yellowspotted catsharks live in the deep western Indian Ocean.
Freckled catsharks are covered with speckled patterns like freckles.
African catsharks are bottom-dwelling species with little-known habits.
Natal shysharks curl into a donut shape to protect themselves.
East African catsharks live along the coasts of Kenya and Tanzania.
